Local police debunked the claim: The expert's verdict mentions that the Buckeye Police Department described the social media chatter as "misinformation" and stated that the bus was filled with office equipment purchased at a surplus sale, complete with invoices and receipts. This aspect verifies the authenticity of the claim by relying on the statement of local law enforcement.
Close: up pictures and video: The expert's verdict mentions that some online users have pointed to close-up pictures and video purportedly showing a "voting machine" to dispute the official explanation. This aspect verifies the authenticity of the claim by examining visual evidence that allegedly supports the claim.
Identification of the device: The expert's verdict explains that the device shown in the pictures and video is actually a printer that was once part of an ES&S "Ballot on Demand" printing system. It further clarifies that the device is an OKI printer used in the ES&S system. This aspect verifies the authenticity of the claim by providing information about the actual nature of the device.
Incompatibility with Arizona election eq: The expert's verdict states that the device pictured, which is an OKI printer, could not have been used in the Arizona election. It further explains that the approved ballot printing device in Arizona is manufactured by Dominion and is fitted with an HP printer. This aspect verifies the authenticity of the claim by highlighting the inconsistency between the device found on the bus and the approved election equipment in Arizona.
